persona.name: Rowan Park-Bennett

occupation.title: Lead Data Scientist / ML Product Lead
occupation.organization: Praxis Health & Climate (mid-stage private company blending healthcare analytics and climate risk modeling)
occupation.description: Rowan is a senior technical leader responsible for defining product strategy where machine learning models inform both clinical decision workflows and corporate sustainability reporting. She manages a team of 6 data scientists and ML engineers, coordinates with product managers, clinicians, and sustainability analysts, and reports to the VP of Product. Her role blends hands-on model development (causal inference, time-series, NLP for clinical notes), productionization (ML infra, monitoring, A/B and canary deployment), hiring, and stakeholder translation: she prioritizes features by clinical impact and regulatory/compliance risk. She is frequently consulted on ethical model design, interpretability, and data governance. Rowan also contributes to business development conversations with health systems and large employers, supporting proposals with technical feasibility and ROI analysis. Key skills used daily: Python (pandas, scikit-learn, PyTorch), SQL, Docker/Kubernetes basics, experiment design, AWS/GCP, model explainability toolkits, and technical writing for regulatory documents. She mentors junior staff on career development and runs a monthly 'model review' forum for cross-functional teams. Typical challenges: balancing speed of iteration with robustness for healthcare settings, navigating procurement and legal constraints for climate data products, and aligning engineering resources with a busy roadmap.

persona.gender: Cisgender woman (identifies with female assigned at birth)
persona.residence: San Francisco, California, USA (West region), urban suburb (owned townhouse, mortgage)
persona.education: B.S. in Statistics and Computer Science from University of Michigan; M.S. in Computer Science (Machine Learning emphasis) from Stanford University. Capstone project on interpretable machine-learning models for healthcare. Continued professional coursework: executive leadership certificate from UC Berkeley Extension; regular attendance at domain conferences (NeurIPS, Strata Data).
long_term_goals: Lead or co-found a mission-driven technology company that applies data and AI to reduce carbon emissions and improve equitable access to healthcare.
Own a small portfolio of real estate in sustainable, transit-oriented neighborhoods (already owns primary residence; aims to acquire one rental property outside SF).
Be financially independent and able to take extended sabbaticals to travel and pursue creative projects.
Mentor and sponsor at least a dozen early-career women and underrepresented engineers to leadership roles.
Build a durable public voice on climate policy and tech ethics—publish op-eds and speak at policy fora.
Master conversational Spanish for travel and community work in Latin America.
Develop a consistent personal creative practice: produce photographic essays and a small-format photobook about urban nature.
Maintain long-term physical and emotional resilience: complete an Ironman-distance triathlon in her 40s and sustain therapy/meditation practice for life.

style.general_description: Warmly professional, quick-witted and direct. Conversational style blends tech-leaning precision with creative metaphors; often uses data or scientific analogies to explain broader ideas. Prefers clear, actionable language in professional settings and drops into more colloquial, humorous rhythm with friends.
mannerisms_and_vocal: Speaks at a moderate-to-fast pace when excited about a topic, punctuating points with a soft, habitual 'right?' or 'exactly'.
Often starts explanations with a short narrative or example — 'Imagine you're...'.
Has a soft California accent, sometimes clipped when speaking about technical topics.
Laughs easily and uses self-deprecating humor to defuse tension.
Tends to tuck hair behind her ear when thinking or checking code during calls.
Habitually carries a stainless-steel tumbler and taps it lightly when pausing to gather thoughts.
Prefers email and asynchronous Slack for work decisions but values short synchronous huddles to unblock teams.
Uses concise bullet points in written communications; annotates documents with clear 'what/why/ask' headers.
Polite but unafraid to interrupt to correct inaccuracies; does so gently and with data.
In social settings, alternates between being an engaged listener and launching into a detailed travel anecdote.
style.formal_vs_casual: Mixes formal professionalism in meetings (structured agendas, timeboxing, clear owners) with casual friendliness outside of that. In interviews and public talks she is polished; in internal team settings she is more candid and informal.
style.digital_presence: Active on LinkedIn (thoughtful, policy-leaning posts), occasional Twitter/X threads about climate+tech, maintains a personal blog with long-form essays on ethics in ML and field notes from travel.

traits: Curious: constantly seeks novel ideas and cross-disciplinary connections.
Ambitious: sets challenging career and personal goals and pursues them methodically.
Empathetic: genuinely interested in other people's experiences and career growth.
Risk-tolerant: comfortable making decisions under uncertainty, especially in startups and product pivots.
Organized: keeps structured calendars, handles multiple projects without dropping commitments.
Sociable: enjoys dinners, industry meetups, and hosting small groups at home.
Reflective: keeps a short daily journal and schedules a monthly 'retrospective' for life decisions.
Impatient with bureaucracy: prefers to find lean, pragmatic paths to impact and resists needless process.
Playful creativity: takes improv classes and approaches brainstorming with humor.
Principled: holds strong ethical stances on sustainability, equity, and responsible tech deployment.
Adaptable: can change course quickly when evidence suggests a better option.
Self-critical: pushes herself hard and sometimes internalizes perceived failures.
personality.notes_on_big_five: Openness very high—loves new ideas, travel, art, and cross-domain learning. Conscientiousness high—organized and reliable. Extraversion moderate-high—energized by social and networking events though values downtime. Agreeableness moderately high—collaborative and mentoring but willing to be tough when necessary. Neuroticism below average—generally resilient, but can experience stress during high-stakes product launches.

general_interests: Sustainable urban design and transit policy
Modern jazz and indie folk music
Travel focused on culture and ecosystems (e.g., Iceland, Taiwan, Oaxaca)
Podcasts on climate policy, data ethics, and leadership
Weekend makerspace woodshop projects (small furniture, shelving)
Improv comedy classes and occasional open-mic storytelling

food_and_drink.overall_preferences: Mostly pescatarian leaning toward seasonal, plant-forward meals; enjoys richly spiced Asian flavors and farm-to-table California cuisine.
coffee_shop_details: Prefers third-wave coffee shops with clear sourcing and barista knowledge.
Favorite drink: single-origin pour-over (often Ethiopian or Kenyan), sometimes a Yirgacheffe.
Morning ritual: a medium-bodied pour-over on weekdays; a cortado on weekend mornings.
Ambiance preference: natural light, plants, a mix of communal and quiet tables, vinyl playing low in the background.
Seating: chooses a corner table near an outlet when working remotely for 90+ minutes.
Chains she tolerates: Blue Bottle for consistency; avoids giant corporate chains when possible.
Snacks she pairs with coffee: almond croissant, sesame seaweed rolls, or a bánh mì on weekends.
Uses a refillable stainless-steel tumbler and prefers places that offer discounts for bringing it.
Goes to coffee shops to work asynchronously about twice a week, using them as deep-work sessions.
Likes to tip generously for good service and engage baristas about origins.
Prefers oat milk in lattes (barista's choice brand), avoids overly sweet syrups.
Regular spot near home: a neighborhood cafe that supports community makers and posts local art.
Uses coffee shops for informal 1:1 meetings rather than formal interviews.
Dislikes loud music or aggressive playlists in cafes; prefers curated indie or jazz sets.
Keeps a small pocket notebook for sketching data model ideas while sipping coffee.
Orders decaf or half-caf in late afternoons to sleep well.
App choices: often preorders via Square/Toast apps when available.
Brings noise-cancelling earbuds for deep work but removes them to chat with friends.
Views coffee consumption as both fuel and a culturally rich ritual—enjoys learning farmer and coop stories.
Occasionally hosts small coffee-tasting gatherings at home, inviting friends and baristas.
cooking_and_restaurants: Enjoys experimenting with miso, fermented condiments, and shiitake-based broths.
Favorite cuisine rotation: Korean banchan, Mediterranean mezze, Californian farm kitchens, and seafood-focused restaurants.
Vegetables she loves: roasted kohlrabi, charred broccolini, heirloom tomatoes, and maitake mushrooms.
Favorite weekend activity: visiting the Ferry Building farmers' market and buying seasonal produce.
Restaurant etiquette: prefers reservations, values sustainable sourcing, and reads menus for origin notes.
Snack preferences: roasted seaweed squares, dry-roasted edamame, and dark chocolate (70%+).
Wine & cocktails: enjoys natural wines, spritzes with Aperol in summer, and tequila-based cocktails when out.
Dislikes: overly processed sugary breakfast cereals and aggressively sweetened desserts.
Dietary restrictions: avoids red meat for environmental and health reasons; eats seafood occasionally.
Meal-prep: preps grain bowls and roasted vegetable packs for weekday lunches.

books_and_reading: Favors non-fiction on climate science, technology policy, and modern biographies.
Fiction tastes: literary fiction with strong sense of place (e.g., Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie, Yaa Gyasi), occasional Scandinavian noir.
Reads 30–40 books a year; keeps an active reading list and sends recommendations to friends.
Has a bookshelf organized by themes: technology ethics, travel writing, photography monographs, and cookbooks.
Uses a Kindle for travel and physical books at home for display and gift-giving.
music_and_podcasts: Listens to playlists that mix modern jazz, electronic ambient, and singer-songwriter tracks.
Favorite podcasts: The Ezra Klein Show (policy), Lex Fridman (AI & philosophy), How I Built This (entrepreneurship), and a local podcast on San Francisco history.
Attends live music twice a month when touring artists align with tastes; also enjoys small jazz club nights with friends.
visual_arts: Photographs cityscapes and urban nature with a mirrorless camera; shoots film occasionally.
Collects prints from emerging local photographers and supports small gallery shows.
Enjoys visiting museum exhibitions on weekends and writes short reflective notes on favorite works.

travel_style: Prefers immersive trips focusing on local foodways, conservation projects, and off-the-beaten-path neighborhoods.
Often plans trips with a mix of scheduled meaningful activities (visiting a sanctuary, joining a local workshop) and unstructured wandering.

Favorite destinations visited: Hokkaido (nature and food), Oaxaca (crafts and cuisine), Portugal (coastlines and small towns), Iceland (landscapes and geothermal culture), Seoul (family visits and contemporary art).
Packing habits: minimalist carry-on, compressible rain shell, and a Moleskine travel notebook.
Dislikes package tourism and crowded commercial resorts; prefers boutique guesthouses and eco-lodges.

device_habits: Smartphone-first internet access; uses phone for quick email, Slack checks, and social browsing.
High daily screen time: commonly 8–11 hours including work screens; uses screen-time limits for evenings.
Favorites: iPhone with privacy-first settings, lightweight MacBook Pro for development, e-ink Kindle for reading.
Streaming: subscribes to Netflix, MUBI (for indie films), and a curated documentary service; listens to Spotify Premium and uses curated playlists.
Social media: active on LinkedIn for professional network, Twitter/X for tech policy and climate thought leadership, Instagram for photography (private account used selectively).
Productivity tools: Notion for knowledge management, Todoist for tasks, Slack for team communication, and Google Workspace for docs and scheduling.
Prefers asynchronous, documented decisions and separate channels for 'deep work' to minimize interruptions.
Uses a mechanical keyboard at home and a compact travel keyboard when remote working.
Has a modest smart-home setup: smart thermostat, lights, and a battery backup; prefers manual control for most devices.

social_life_and_entertaining: Hosts bi-monthly small dinner parties focused on plant-forward menus and curated playlists.
Enjoys organized group hikes, photography walks, and weekend getaway planning with close friends.
Values a core group of ~6 close friends for nightly chats and a larger circle for monthly social events.
Often volunteers time for local climate advocacy groups and women-in-tech mentorship events.

beliefs: Climate change is an existential crisis that requires immediate structural policy action and private-sector innovation.
Economic growth must be decoupled from carbon emissions; incentives and regulations should accelerate that decoupling.
Progressive social policy is necessary to reduce inequality and create fair access to healthcare and education.
Healthcare should be accessible and affordable; data and tech must be used to expand access responsibly.
Technology is a tool, not a destiny: ethics and governance should shape how AI is applied in healthcare and climate.
Transparency in algorithms and datasets is essential for public trust and accountability.
Corporate sustainability claims should be subject to rigorous verification to avoid greenwashing.
Public investment in transit and walkable neighborhoods yields better social and environmental outcomes than unfettered suburban sprawl.
Urban planning should prioritize affordable housing near transit to reduce commute emissions and increase equity.
Diversity in tech teams leads to better products and fewer blind spots in model design.
Data privacy is a human right; default opt-in practices are unacceptable.
Government should subsidize renewable energy infrastructure and retraining programs for affected workers.
Progressive taxation, combined with targeted social programs, can help reduce structural inequality without crushing innovation.
Philanthropy can be catalytic but cannot replace systemic policy solutions.
Evidence-based policymaking should be the norm; randomized trials and careful evaluation are important in social programs.
Small individual consumer choices matter less than systemic choices by corporations and governments, though personal behavior still has symbolic and aggregate effects.
Workplaces should support flexible schedules and remote options to improve wellbeing and reduce commuting footprints.
Mental health access is as important as physical health—insurance and workplace culture must reflect that.
Science and data should guide pandemic and disaster responses, combined with humility about uncertainty.
Corporate boards should be held accountable for environmental and social metrics, not just short-term profit.
Education systems must be reoriented to teach critical thinking, digital literacy, and civic engagement.
Urban trees and green infrastructure provide measurable health and climate resilience benefits and should be prioritized.
High earners should contribute more to solving social problems, both through taxation and voluntary civic engagement.
Electoral participation should be made easier: mail-in voting, expanded polling access, and civic education.
Local communities know their needs best; participatory budgeting and community-centered design yield better outcomes.
Tech regulation should be pragmatic—encourage innovation but set clear guardrails for harmful use cases (surveillance, manipulative personalization).
Open-source tools and academic-public-private partnerships are powerful levers for equitable technological progress.
Startups should measure success by social impact metrics as well as growth metrics, especially in areas touching public goods.
Sustainability policies should include a just transition for workers and communities dependent on high-carbon industries.
Cross-border cooperation on climate finance and technology transfer is essential; wealthy nations have an obligation to support adaptation.
Personal responsibility matters—she reduces waste, eats plant-forward, and uses public transit—but systemic reform is the multiplier.
Science communication must be empathetic and actionable to build public buy-in for policy change.
Privacy-preserving data analysis (differential privacy, federated learning) should be prioritized in health and public-sector projects.
Small pilot projects can be a useful path to scaling—but pilots must be designed for rigorous evaluation and realistic scaling constraints.
She believes in incremental institutional improvements and occasional bold, structural reforms when the political window opens.
Community-oriented businesses (B Corps, cooperatives) can be an important part of a mixed-economy solution to inequality and sustainability.
skills: Advanced statistical modeling and causal inference (A/B testing, propensity scores, instrumental variables).
Hands-on machine learning: supervised/unsupervised models, time-series forecasting, NLP (clinical text) with PyTorch and Transformers.
Production ML: model deployment patterns, monitoring, drift detection, CI/CD for ML, Docker, and experience with Kubernetes orchestration.
Data engineering fundamentals: SQL at scale, ETL design patterns, familiarity with Spark and cloud storage.
Quantitative product management: translating model metrics into user/customer KPIs and business impact.
Leadership and people management: hiring, performance reviews, career laddering, mentoring under-represented engineers.
Technical writing and documentation: can produce clear technical briefs for non-technical stakeholders and regulatory audiences.
Experiment design and causal evaluation for product and policy interventions.
Public speaking and thought leadership: presents at conferences, runs workshops, and leads panel discussions.
Cross-functional stakeholder management: collaborates with clinicians, sustainability analysts, legal, and sales.
Languages: fluent English, conversational Korean, basic Spanish.
Personal productivity: advanced use of Notion, task batching, and calendar-slicing for deep work.
Basic financial literacy: comfortable interpreting P&L, unit economics, and supporting go-to-market projections.
Photography: competent technical camera skills (manual exposure, composition, film processing basics).
First aid and wilderness basics (WFA-level knowledge) useful on outdoor trips.

general: Schedules 'deep work' blocks early in the morning and avoids meetings before 10 AM when possible.
Conducts brief 'standup plus' each Monday to align on priorities and raises blockers proactively.
Maintains a curated 'no meeting' afternoon twice a week for heads-down engineering and writing.
Keeps a small paper journal for daily gratitude and quick sketches; uses Notion for long-form notes.
Uses a Pomodoro rhythm when tackling long coding or writing sessions (50/10 rhythm).
Exercises consistently: 3–5 runs or cycling sessions per week, mixing intervals and long slow distance.
Moderates alcohol consumption—prefers quality over quantity at social events.
Maintains a therapy practice (weekly or bi-weekly) and a meditation habit (10–20 minutes most days).
Volunteers monthly at a coding workshop for high-school students and mentors through a women-in-tech program.
When stressed, goes for a 30-minute walk to reset rather than immediately checking email.

morning: Quick mobility routine and 20–30 minute run or indoor trainer session three times a week.
Breakfast: overnight oats or smoked salmon toast with a small pour-over coffee.
Skims headlines and Slack during a 20-minute commute (bikes to light-rail then walks).
First work block: 90–120 minutes of deep technical work (modeling, writing).
workday: Checks calendar and priorities after morning standup; blocks time for code review and mentoring sessions.
Lunch: often a short walk and a packed grain bowl or a neighborhood cafe salad; eats mindfully.
Afternoon: cross-functional meetings, demos, stakeholder syncs, and occasional customer calls.
Ends formal work day by 6 PM, but may do a short email pass later if on a tight deadline.
Allocates one hour per week to reading recent research papers relevant to climate/health ML.
evening: Cooks dinner 4–5 nights a week; enjoys experimenting with new plant-forward recipes.
Evening social time: hosts friends, attends a meetup, or watches a documentary with a glass of wine.
Spends 20 minutes journaling and a short guided meditation before bed.
Usually in bed by 11 PM, aiming for 7–8 hours of sleep.
weekend: Longer runs or cycling rides on Saturdays; photography walks in the morning.
Visits farmers' markets, attends gallery openings, and meets a friend for brunch.
Sundays reserved for lower-energy planning: review finances, meal prep, and extended reading or a museum visit.
Occasionally travels for quick 2–3 day trips to nearby nature areas or out-of-state cities.

physical.general_state: Generally healthy and fit; maintains regular cardio and strength routine. BMI in a healthy range.
physical.conditions_and_history: No chronic diseases. Past sports-related sprain (left ankle) repaired with conservative therapy. Seasonal allergies (pollen) managed with antihistamines during spring. Mild adult-onset shoulder tendonitis from heavy lifting several years ago, managed with physio.
physical.preventive_care: Annual physical exams, routine dental cleanings, and proactive screening appropriate for age. Vaccinations up to date.
physical.sleep: Typically sleeps 7–8 hours nightly, uses sleep hygiene routines (dark room, screens off at least 30 minutes before bed).
physical.nutrition: Mostly plant-forward diet, occasional fish. Keeps an eye on iron and B12 levels annually. Drinks water throughout the day; limits caffeine to mornings.

mental.wellbeing: Stable mood with realistic stress during high-pressure work cycles. Practices weekly therapy and mindfulness to maintain resilience.
mental.history: Mild periods of anxiety during intense startup fundraising cycles in her early 30s; learned coping strategies (CBT techniques, breathing exercises). No history of hospitalization.
mental.stress_management: Uses therapy, meditation, physical activity, social support, and short digital-detox weekends as primary tools.

relationships.status: Single (actively dating occasionally, not in a serious relationship). No children (explicitly).
relationships.attitude: Values deep compatibility, shared values around sustainability and curiosity. Prefers partners who are communicative, growth-oriented, and emotionally available.

members: Mother: Ji-yeon Park (early 60s), born in South Korea, immigrated to the U.S. in her 20s; retired public-school teacher living in the East Bay; close relationship and weekly phone calls.
Father: Michael Bennett (early 60s), American-born systems engineer; lives in Seattle; cordial relationship, enjoys technical conversations and occasional joint travel.
Younger cousin: Min-soo Park (mid-20s), lives in Seoul, works in design; they exchange photography tips and travel stories.

list: Tara Nguyen — former coworker and now product designer; weekly Sunday calls and frequent dinners.
Ethan Ruiz — college friend and startup founder; they exchange ideas on entrepreneurship and occasionally cohost panels.
Sofia Martinez — close friend from grad school, now a physician; they discuss health-care policy and family.
Priya Agarwal — mentee-turned-peer in ML; they collaborate on a women-in-tech mentorship program.

relationships.description: Wide network across healthcare, climate policy, and ML research. Maintains strong ties at Stanford, past colleagues at two startups, and several industry mentors including a VP of Engineering at a large health-tech firm and a policy advisor at a climate NGO.

other_facts: Born in Ann Arbor, Michigan; spent formative years in the Midwest and later moved to the West Coast for graduate school.
Given name 'Rowan' chosen by parents for its gender-neutral quality and connection to nature; family uses both Park and Bennett surnames to reflect mixed heritage.
Bilingual household influences: grew up speaking English at school and English/Korean at home; kept conversational Korean and visits relatives in Seoul every 2–3 years.
At age 16, won a regional math competition and later used that early confidence to pursue data science.
In college, took a semester abroad in Copenhagen studying urban design and was struck by transit-first city planning.
Started first tech internship building data dashboards at a healthcare startup during undergrad; that experience framed her interest in practical ML for health.
Worked at a small health-tech startup after undergrad, then moved to a FAANG-level research group for rigorous ML exposure, then returned to startups for product impact.
Once turned down a lucrative tenure-track academic offer because she preferred building products with immediate social impact.
Had an early-career mentoring relationship that changed her approach to management; she now pays it forward with structured mentorship programs.
Owns a 2-bedroom townhouse in a walkable San Francisco suburb (mortgage) bought in her early 30s; chosen intentionally for commute-access, daylight, and a small garden space she tends to.
Has no children by choice and is comfortable with that decision while remaining open to future conversations; explicitly values the freedom to pursue demanding career and travel goals.
Experienced a difficult breakup in her early 30s that led to deeper therapy work and a stronger sense of boundaries; she views it as a growth pivot.
Is an avid amateur photographer—has an archive of several thousand curated images, and occasionally sells small zines at local markets.
Volunteered pro bono consultancy for a community health clinic to build a patient outreach model that increased vaccination outreach by 12% in a pilot.
Was part of a cross-functional team that successfully navigated HIPAA-compliant data sharing between a health system and a nonprofit.
Has published two co-authored white papers on responsible ML for clinical settings and was a guest on a podcast about AI governance.
Her childhood hobbies included rock-climbing and piano; she still climbs occasionally and plays piano to relax.
Prefers experiences over possessions: invests in travel, small workshops, and local craft rather than designer goods.
Keeps a modest emergency fund covering 9 months of expenses and invests in index funds and green-themed ETFs.
At 34, completed a month-long solo trip through Iceland and wrote a 12-part blog series on energy transitions and local adaptation measures.
Has a ritual of sending hand-written postcards to a small circle of friends while traveling.
Once co-organized a neighborhood resilience planning workshop after a winter storm; contributed to a local microgrid discussion group.
Enjoys small woodworking projects in a local makerspace; built a custom bike rack and a set of floating shelves for her home.
Attends an annual 'women in AI' retreat where she both mentors and leads a breakout session on ethical design.
Has a slightly neurotic habit of double-checking doors and the stove before leaving home; uses a checklist app to calm that anxiety.
Collects vinyl records of modern jazz and prefers listening to them on Sunday mornings while cooking.
Is allergic to cats (mild) but loves dogs; volunteers occasionally at a shelter for walking dogs.
Was awarded an internal company 'Values in Action' award for mentoring and building a reproducible model review process.
Keeps a small garden with native pollinator plants (lavender, California poppy, rosemary) and takes pride in creating habitat for bees and butterflies.
Has a distinct scar on the left forearm from a childhood bike accident; it's a little story she tells when meeting new friends.
Favors bicycle commuting when weather allows and participates in a local bike co-op for maintenance workshops.
Has an informal tradition of planning a 'future self' letter each birthday with concrete 3-year goals and reflections; she uses these letters to recalibrate life choices.
Enjoys cooking collaborative meals with friends where each person brings one course and a story tied to it.
Believes in documenting small rituals to maintain continuity in a fast-moving life: morning tea, Sunday planning, and a monthly 'analog day' with no screens.
Kept a small capsule wardrobe to simplify choices; values quality and ethical manufacturing over fast fashion.
Often experiences 'productive anxiety' that she channels into structuring tasks and breaking down large projects into measurable milestones.
Loves cityscapes at dawn and often takes photos during early morning walks to capture that quiet window of the city.
Has a favorite mentor—an older clinician-scientist—who taught her the importance of humility when working with clinical teams.
Even though she frequently moves fast professionally, she is slow to adopt new social apps—prefers ones that respect privacy and have clear value.
